page_analysis.text_content:
Other excavation considerations

Architectural compatibility & landscape screening

• If a guard rail is required, it must be designed to be archi-
tecturally compatible with the residence.

• Additionally, landscape screening may be required by the
Planning Dept.

Tree protection

• A tree's root system extends well beyond the drip line and the
roots are likely to be within the first 18" below grade.

• It is important to plan excavation in a manner that does not
harm tree roots.

• Prior to issuance of building permit, owner to provide evidence
that encroaching features or portions of features will not harm
trees of any species on subject or abutting lots.

• Consult the city's Tree Technical Manual for other aspects of
tree protection during construction.

Fig 37 Excavation, landscape screening, and guard rails

Fig 38 Excavation and tree roots

Basement
Excav
featur

When planning a basement, consider the
extent of excavation that will be required e.g.,
some excavation techniques require (for safety
reasons) that the excavation to be at a 1:1
slope which may impact tree roots severely.

41

visual_elements.description: Figure 37: A cross-sectional diagram illustrating a building with a basement and an adjacent excavated area. The building has siding and a window. The ground is shown with dashed lines indicating the original grade and a sloped excavated area. There are small hatched patterns representing earth. The text 'Basement' is vertically aligned on the building's foundation, and 'Excav featur' is vertically aligned next to the excavated area.

Figure 38: A cross-sectional diagram showing a building with a basement and an adjacent tree. The building's foundation is labeled 'Basement'. The ground is shown with a tree, its root system, and a sloped excavated area. A dashed line indicates the original grade, and a solid line indicates the excavation slope. The text 'Excav featur' is vertically aligned next to the excavated area. An annotation below the diagram discusses basement planning and excavation slopes impacting tree roots.

Prior to issuance of building permit
some excavation techniques require (for safety reasons)

conditions.text: it must be designed to be architecturally compatible with the residence.
landscape screening may be required by the Planning Dept.
A tree's root system extends well beyond the drip line and the roots are likely to be within the first 18" below grade.
owner to provide evidence that encroaching features or portions of features will not harm trees of any species on subject or abutting lots.
conditions.threshold_value: no harm to trees from encroaching features

conditions.text: Consult the city's Tree Technical Manual for other aspects of tree protection during construction.
consider the extent of excavation that will be required
the excavation to be at a 1:1 slope which may impact tree roots severely.

logical_relationships.expression: It is important to plan excavation in a manner that does not harm tree roots.

execution_sequence.action: Evaluate if a guard rail is required.
If a guard rail is required, ensure it is designed to be architecturally compatible with the residence.
Note that landscape screening may be required by the Planning Dept.
Consider that a tree's root system extends beyond the drip line and roots are likely within the first 18" below grade.
Plan excavation in a manner that does not harm tree roots.
Prior to building permit issuance, owner must provide evidence that encroaching features will not harm trees.
Consult the city's Tree Technical Manual for tree protection during construction.
When planning a basement, consider the required excavation extent.
If excavation techniques require a 1:1 slope for safety, be aware of potential severe impact on tree roots.
